_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The management of Lumileds is committed to maintaining a safe work environment. The Environmental Engineer has been assigned to ensure that safe practices are followed in the specification and operation of systems involving hazardous chemicals. The site has specific and written evacuation, reporting, and response procedures in place to protect Lumileds employees, the public, and the environment in the event of an ammonia release. 

Stationary Source and Regulated Substance

Lumileds is operating four ISO containers containing 26,400 lb.  each of high purity white anhydrous ammonia with two online and two in standby. Each ISO container has the following safety equipment: 0.171" restricted flow orifice, excess flow mechanical switch and air operated fail-closed control valve. Each ISO container is connected to a dedicated GASGUARD® Very High Flow System (VFFS) with an AP11 controller monitors temperature and pressure of each ISO container. Following the VFFS there are associated gas distribution systems, tools, detection and abatement systems (Wet Scrubbers and Adsorbent (Purafil) Abatement System). The ISO containers and VFFS system have a Pad #1 (Right/West Side) and Pad #2 (Left/East Side). Each Pad (side) has one ISO container online and one ISO container in standby. The Pad #1 (Right/West Side) and Pad #2 (Left/East Side) have one line that flows to Manual Valve Manifold Box (VMB) which has a common header with a typically open valve between Pad #1 (Right/West Side) and Pad #2 (Left/East Side). The VMB header feeds the MOCVD reactors within the facility. The lines from the VMB to MOCVD reactors contain equipment to filter, regulate, purify, and monitor flows from the bulk ammonia containers.  See Attachment One for Flow Schematic.

In addition to using Versum Material's proven safety control systems, Lumileds has performed a process hazard analysis (PHA) on the bulk ammonia syst

em to verify that all safety and engineering controls are in place.  The PHA was last revalidated 2020.

The site includes a building with a facilities pad, an ammonia ISO container enclosure that contains the four bulk anhydrous ammonia ISO containers, and an ammonia Purafil abatement system. 

This anhydrous ammonia system is the only process at this site to which the CALARP RMP requirements are applicable.

Release Scenarios

The worst-case release quantity was defined as the total quantity of anhydrous ammonia in the online Bulk Anhydrous Ammonia ISO Tank and MOCVD Tools system or a ruptured ISO tank (i.e. 26,400 pounds). Since the vessel is located outdoors, there are no mitigating controls assumed.

The alternative release scenarios considered both the five-year accident history and the results of the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) study conducted at Lumileds on April 3rd, April 28th and April 29th of 2020. When these other scenarios were evaluated, the end results were no worse than the selected alternative release scenario. The selected alternative release scenario assumed that the gas line from the bulk anhydrous ammonia ISO Tank was broken and the tank released at the maximum anhydrous ammonia gas flow rate of 49.75 lbs./min with the excess flow valve closing in 1 minute.

    The selected scenario was determined as the most likely scenario that would have an off-site exposure. The release point would be at the ammonia enclosure where the Bulk Anhydrous Ammonia ISO tanks are stored and that the release is not contained within the system exhausted enclosure. The line that may release is between the ISO tank and the high pressure regulator enclosure.  

Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Prevention of accidental ammonia releases at Lumileds is accomplished through: 

-    Sound industry practice anhydrous ammonia tonner 

-    Aixtron tool system design and construction,

-    Specification and review of system modifications,

-    Day-to-day operation and maintenance of the system.  

This includes:

?    Compliance with industry standards and codes in effect at the time of initial construction and modification;

o    California Building Code 2001 and 2007; California Fire Code 2001 and 2007; 2002 and 2009 San Jose Municipal Code - Examples includes:

    Excess flow control/pressure release valves limit the maximum flow of ammonia from the ISO container to 2,985 lb./hr. or 49.75 lb./min  

    Restricted flow orifices (RFO) are installed in the valves on each ISO container with a diameter of 0.171 inches - maximum flow rate of 3694 LPM (130 CFM or 5.7 lb./min ) of gaseous NH3.  

    Ammonia sensors are designed to automatically shut-off flow of ammonia and direct all exhaust into the scrubbers for treatment. Ammonia control valves are fail-closed valves.

    All mechanical fittings are exhausted with a flow rate that is greater than or equal to the RFO release rate per the Test and Balance Report, dated 7/16/2019, and is designed to capture an ammonia leak at any fittings/connections.

    Exhaust ventilation/treatment system has emergency back-up power.

?    Performance of a thorough Process Hazard Analyses (PHA) at least once every five years using accurate Process Safety Information; 

?    Implementation of Operating Procedures which have been reviewed by PHA; 

?    Appropriate initial and refresher training of system operations and maintenance personnel;  

?    Performance of preventive and corrective maintenance according to system component manufacturer recommendations and pursuant to site wide hazardous energy lockout and hot work permit programs;

?    Application of established auditing, inspection, and pre-start-up review protocols; and

?    Use of qualified contractors for work on the system.

Five Year Accident History

There has not been any ammonia releases resulting in onsite or off-site injuries, deaths, or property damage, or in off-site environmental damage, evacu

ations, or sheltering in place.  

Emergency Response Program

Lumileds has well-established emergency procedures and an active Emergency Response Team (ERT) on site to ensure rapid and appropriate response to hazardous material emergencies, including response to emergencies related to the regulated substances covered by this RMP. 

The emergency response procedures are contained in the Emergency Response Team Plan, accessible at the site and maintained by the ERT Program Manager. The document describes response procedures for various emergency scenarios, including the mitigation of hazardous material releases, agency notification procedures in the event of a hazardous material release, and emergency equipment available at the site. 

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Based on the studies conducted during preparation of this RMP, the 22 recommendations have been documented and are expected to be completed by 12/31/2020.
